verses.verse: (Eliphaz Speaks: Job Has Sinned) Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered:
(Job 32.18-20) “If one ventures a word with you, will you be offended? But who can keep from speaking?
(Isa 35.3; Heb 12.12) See, you have instructed many; you have strengthened the weak hands.
(Isa 35.3; Heb 12.12) Your words have supported those who were stumbling, and you have made firm the feeble knees.
(Job 6.14; 19.21) But now it has come to you, and you are impatient; it touches you, and you are dismayed.
(Job 1.1) Is not your fear of God your confidence and the integrity of your ways your hope?
(Ps 37.25) “Think now, who that was innocent ever perished? Or where were the upright cut off?
(Prov 22.8; Hos 10.13; Gal 6.7, 8) As I have seen, those who plow iniquity and sow trouble reap the same.
(Job 15.30; Ps 59.13; Isa 30.33) By the breath of God they perish, and by the blast of his anger they are consumed.
(Ps 58.6) The roar of the lion, the voice of the fierce lion, and the teeth of the young lions are broken.
(Ps 34.10) The strong lion perishes for lack of prey, and the whelps of the lioness are scattered.
(Job 26.14) “Now a word came stealing to me; my ear received the whisper of it.
Amid thoughts from visions of the night, when deep sleep falls on mortals,
(Jer 23.9) dread came upon me and trembling, which made all my bones shake.
A spirit glided past my face; the hair of my flesh bristled.
It stood still, but I could not discern its appearance. A form was before my eyes; there was silence; then I heard a voice:
(Job 9.2; 35.10) ‘Can mortals be righteous before (Or more righteous than) God? Can humans be pure before (Or more pure than) their Maker?
(Job 15.15) Even in his servants he puts no trust, and his angels he charges with error;
(Job 10.9; 22.16) how much more those who live in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, who are crushed like a moth.
(Job 20.7; Ps 90.5, 6) Between morning and evening they are destroyed; they perish forever without any regarding it.
(Job 36.12) Their tent cord is plucked up within them, and they die devoid of wisdom.’
